error_description: SQL injection vulnerability: getByUsername() constructs SQL with unescaped user input (username) directly concatenated into query string. This is a nonmalicious development fault (design/implementation, software, internal, dormant until attacker supplies crafted username). High risk of data breach or privilege escalation if activated.

Null dereference: checkLogin() calls userRepository.findByUsername(username).get() without checking if result is present. If username does not exist, NoSuchElementException will be thrown. This is a nonmalicious development fault (implementation, software, internal). Can cause erratic/halt failure on invalid login attempt.

Sensitive information exposure: Logging user password in plaintext in save() method (LOG.debug). This is a nonmalicious development fault (implementation, software, internal). If logs are accessed, user credentials may be compromised. Dormant unless log level is DEBUG and logs are accessible.

Inconsistent password hashing: save() uses a new BCryptPasswordEncoder instance instead of the injected passwordEncoder bean. This is a nonmalicious development fault (implementation, software, internal). May cause authentication failures if encoder configuration differs from the rest of the application.

Inconsistent password hashing: update() uses a new BCryptPasswordEncoder instance instead of the injected passwordEncoder bean. This is a nonmalicious development fault (implementation, software, internal). May cause authentication failures if encoder configuration differs from the rest of the application.

User deletion does not actually remove user from database: delete() method only loads user and logs deletion, but does not call userRepository.delete(). This is a nonmalicious development fault (implementation, software, internal). Results in latent error: users remain in DB after delete request, leading to data inconsistency and possible privilege retention.

Unchecked Optional: getById() calls addressRepository.findById(addressId).get() without checking if result is present. If address does not exist, NoSuchElementException will be thrown. This is a nonmalicious development fault (implementation, software, internal). Can cause erratic/halt failure on invalid address lookup.

Entity not persisted: save() creates Address entity from DTO and user, but does not persist it (missing addressRepository.save(addressEntity)). Only mapping and response are returned. This is a nonmalicious development fault (implementation, software, internal). Latent error: address is not stored in DB, but response implies success.
